extraction_metadata.article_title: A Study on a Decentralized SaaS Business Model

extracted_data.question_text: What is the name and definition of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.extracted_value: Decentralized SaaS Business Model - A distributed business model where local servers are independent business entities that compete with each other to maximize their own profit while providing similar services/applications to customers, as an alternative to centralized SaaS models to avoid single-point-of-failure problems and investment/management issues.
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1, Abstract: 'We propose a decentralized SaaS (Software as a Service) business model and compare it with a common centralized model in cloud computing.' | Page 2, Section III: 'A decentralized business model of SaaS is illustrated in Figure 2.' | Page 2, Section III: 'In this case, local servers are competing with each other to maximize their own profit; meanwhile, they may provide similar services/applications to their customers.'

extracted_data.question_text: What synonyms or alternative terms are used in the article to refer to this software business model?
extracted_value: distributed business model
decentralized model
semi-cooperative SaaS market
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2, Section III: 'A decentralized business model of SaaS is illustrated in Figure 2.' | Page 2, Section III: 'To avoid either one, we propose and analyze a distributed business model, which could be an alternative here.' | Page 5, Section V: 'various effects caused by different service selection strategies in a semi-cooperative SaaS market'

extracted_data.question_text: What is the main vertical segment or industry where the software business model presented in the article is applied?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1, Abstract: 'we show our study on a market model of mobile SaaS (Software as a Service) servers in a semi-cooperative environment' | Page 1, Abstract: 'We propose a decentralized SaaS (Software as a Service) business model'

extracted_data.question_text: What type of network effect is present in the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3, Section IV: 'if N clients request the same service, which is only provided by a server, then the queue length will be N. But if two servers could provide the same service, the queue length reduced to N/2, which means a better QoS'

extracted_value: Direct sales

extracted_data.question_text: Which Business Model Canvas elements are detailed in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Value Proposition: Decentralized SaaS services to avoid single-point-of-failure and reduce investment/management issues
Customer Segment: Small to mid-size providers and end users
Revenue Streams: License fees based on users/usage
Key Resources: Local servers, HQ brand products, R&D capabilities
Key Activities: Service provision, global advertisement, training
Key Partnerships: HQ-local server relationships
Cost Structure: Connection/traffic costs, data center costs
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1, Section I: 'To avoid either one, we propose and analyze a distributed business model, which could be an alternative here.' | Page 2, Section III: 'A benefit for HQ is it can save the connection/traffic cost, use less data center, and concentrate on its product development.' | Page 2, Section III: 'HQ may have some brand products and responsible for their global advertisement, R&D, and training.'

extracted_data.question_text: Which actors participate in the ecosystem of the software business model presented in the article and how do they interact?
extracted_data.extracted_value: HQ | Brand management, R&D, training | Provides brand products and support to local servers | Manages global advertisement | Local servers | Service provision | Pay license fees to HQ, compete with other servers | Serve customers directly | Customers | Service consumption | Interact with local servers | Receive services from local servers
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2, Section III: 'HQ may have some brand products and responsible for their global advertisement, R&D, and training' | Page 2, Section III: 'local servers will get some supports from their HQ and pay license fee according to the number of users or usages' | Page 2, Section III: 'local servers are competing with each other to maximize their own profit'

extracted_data.question_text: What motivations lead to the adoption of the software business model presented in the article?
extracted_value: Avoid single-point-of-failure problems
Reduce investment and management issues for growing mid-size providers
Save connection/traffic costs
Use less data centers
Concentrate on product development
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1, Section I: 'when a growing mid-size provider broadening its business to global market, it may suffer from many investment and management issues' | Page 1, Section I: 'when a provider suffers from a server emergency, such as the incident happened in Amazon AWS [2], or a security attack, such as DDoS, the whole chain of its market will face a serious problem, which is commonly known as the single-point-of-failure problem' | Page 2, Section III: 'A benefit for HQ is it can save the connection/traffic cost, use less data center, and concentrate on its product development.'

extracted_data.question_text: What factors contribute to the success of the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Fixed strategy → Highest total revenue and satisfaction rate
Service selection strategies → Revenue optimization
Demand factor calculation → Better service allocation
Load balancing → Reduced response time and increased availability
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4, Section IV: 'Fixed strategy is found to be the best method to earn the highest total revenue for all five servers, with the highest satisfaction rate too.' | Page 3, Section IV: 'It is not only for solving load balancing issue, but also for reducing response time and increasing the availability, which have been considered as major issues in distributed computing.'

extracted_data.question_text: What prerequisites or conditions are necessary for the software business model as described in the article?
extracted_value: Independent business entities → Local server autonomy
Brand products from HQ → Service standardization
License fee structure → Revenue model
Service switching capability → Market responsiveness
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2, Section III: 'local servers are belong to independent business entity' | Page 2, Section III: 'every local server may be required to provide certain applications (e.g. the brand products)' | Page 2, Section III: 'we assume that changing service (installing/uninstalling software) does not consume much time/cost.'

extracted_data.question_text: What restrictions or incompatibilities are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Fixed pricing in oligopolistic model → Limited market responsiveness
Limited simulation scale → Reduced real-world applicability
Equal item prices assumption → Simplified pricing model
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 2, Section III: 'But in our model, we only consider a fixed price, which may be true within a specific time period in an oligopolistic model.' | Page 4, Section IV: 'The first weakness is that the experiment scale (number of servers and clients) were limited' | Page 4, Section IV: 'in the real world, the item prices of all the applications may be different and servers may have different priorities for different applications from their business viewpoint. However, we assumed they are the same here.'

extracted_data.question_text: What challenges are identified in implementing the software business model as presented in the article?
extracted_value: Investment and management issues for growing mid-size providers
Single-point-of-failure problems in centralized models
Server emergency incidents and security attacks
Load balancing and response time optimization
Market demand prediction and service allocation
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1, Section I: 'when a growing mid-size provider broadening its business to global market, it may suffer from many investment and management issues' | Page 1, Section I: 'when a provider suffers from a server emergency, such as the incident happened in Amazon AWS [2], or a security attack, such as DDoS, the whole chain of its market will face a serious problem, which is commonly known as the single-point-of-failure problem' | Page 3, Section IV: 'It is not only for solving load balancing issue, but also for reducing response time and increasing the availability'

Fixed strategy → Maximizes revenue → Highest satisfaction rate

extracted_data.question_text: Which companies or products are cited as examples of the software business model in the article?
extracted_value: Amazon AWS → Example of server emergency incident in centralized model
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 1, Section I: 'when a provider suffers from a server emergency, such as the incident happened in Amazon AWS [2]'

extracted_data.question_text: Are there variations or subtypes of the software business model described in the article?
extracted_value: Fixed strategy → Servers maintain same applications throughout
Poor move strategy → Servers with low revenue move to high-demand applications
Rich move strategy → Capable servers move to highly demanded applications
Poor request-rate move strategy → Servers with low request rate move to high-demand applications
All move strategy → All servers move based on demand
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 3, Section IV: 'five different strategies that may be adopted by servers have been studied, they are: Fixed, All move, Rich move, Poor move, and Poor request-rate move' | Page 3, Section IV: 'In this move, those servers whose request rate is less than the average request rate are defined as poor.'

extracted_data.question_text: What future trends or evolutions are mentioned in the article about the software business model?
extracted_value: Fast learning methods for recognizing periodic patterns
Auction mechanisms between servers and clients
Bundle applications instead of individual applications
Extended simulation scope with millions of clients and server clusters
Different item prices and server priorities
Client quitting behavior when waiting in queue
extracted_data.source_citation: Page 4, Section IV: 'To improve the server revenue (and also the satisfaction rate), a fast learning method or a method that can recognize the periodic pattern should be adopted, which are left for the future work.' | Page 4, Section IV: 'For example, if auction between servers and clients are allowed or servers can provide the applications in a bundle instead of providing them in individual applications, then they may increase clients' loyalty and the revenue.' | Page 4, Section IV: 'we also can add some assumptions such as the number of clients may decrease (quit) when they are waiting in the queue which is common in the reality.'
